issue.title: Specify `site_url` in MkDocs configuration for correct sitemap
issue.body:
Fixes #1053.

To correctly generate the `sitemap.xml`, the [`site_url` must be specified in `mkdocs.yml`](https://github.com/mkdocs/mkdocs/issues/1783).

Having a valid sitemap can help search engines [index a site's content](https://developers.google.com/search/docs/crawling-indexing/sitemaps/overview).

What I've done here is to make `site_url` switchable depending on an environment variable, `MKDOCS_SITE_URL` and then simply set that on build. As this is only really required for deployment, I've just put this in the deployment workflow, instead of adding some wrapper or to do the build with the environment variable supplied.

This keeps the local development setup exactly as it was, with no value set for `site_url`.

I'm reasonably convinced that this is the right approach because:

* we can override the `site_url`
  * to set as an empty string if we ever want to build a [local file distribution](https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/deploying-your-docs/#local-files) (this may not be necessary with a missing value, but not tested)
  * when running locally with no URL set, the configuration is as it was previously (although I think with `mkdocs serve`, the site URL is ignored anyway!)
* we probably do want the canonical URL to be `https://docs.opensafely.org/some-path…` even for Cloudflare test deployments, technically

comment.body:
> I'm reasonably convinced that this is the right approach…

…but am happy to be persuaded otherwise, that, for instance, we should only set `site_url` for actual production deployments to the site (and not for other Cloudflare Pages previews that we get)

issue.title: `sitemap.xml` not correctly generated for production site

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

issue.body:
Locally, it works:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<urlset xmlns="http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9">
    <url>
         <loc>http://127.0.0.1:8000/</loc>
         <lastmod>2022-12-08</lastmod>
         <changefreq>daily</changefreq>
    </url>
    <url>
         <loc>http://127.0.0.1:8000/access-policies/</loc>
         <lastmod>2022-12-08</lastmod>
         <changefreq>daily</changefreq>
    </url>
…
```

But on the [production site](https://docs.opensafely.org/sitemap.xml),

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<urlset xmlns="http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9">
    <url>
         <loc>None</loc>
         <lastmod>2022-12-08</lastmod>
         <changefreq>daily</changefreq>
    </url>
    <url>
         <loc>None</loc>
         <lastmod>2022-12-08</lastmod>
         <changefreq>daily</changefreq>
    </url>
…
```

The fix is to specify `site_url: https://docs.opensafely.org` in `mkdocs.yml`.

However, I'm not sure we want this setting globally: strictly speaking, for local development and temporary Cloudflare PR, the site URL is different.

It is possible to [customise this, as I previously mentioned](https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/pull/327#issuecomment-883324756); I hadn't realised that this issue broke the sitemap.

issue.title: Add structure to URLs of databuilder docs

labels.name: data builder
labels.description: Data Builder-related documentation issues

issue.body:
The URL structure of the OpenSAFELY documentation is currently flat.  It would be neater (and would make the docs source code easier to navigate) if the URLs were nested.  For instance:

| old | new |
|-|-|
| https://docs.opensafely.org/data-builder-toc/ | https://docs.opensafely.org/data-builder/ |
| https://docs.opensafely.org/ehrql-intro/ | https://docs.opensafely.org/data-builder/ehrql/ |
| https://docs.opensafely.org/ehrql-tutorial/ | https://docs.opensafely.org/data-builder/ehrql/tutorial/ |

We can start with the databuilder (or is it data-builder?) docs since these are unused and we don't have to worry about redirects.

issue.title: Semantic prefixes in PR titles don't trigger a release
issue.body:
By pre-pending "fix:" to [this PR](https://github.com/opensafely/cohort-extractor/pull/240) title, the PR passed the [semantic-pull-requests check](https://github.com/zeke/semantic-pull-requests).

However when merged it didn't then trigger a new release:
```
Analyzing commit: Merge pull request #240 from opensafely/sqlcmd-improvements
fix: Refactor sqlcmd wrapper for better error handling
The commit should not trigger a release
Analyzing commit: Be slightly more defensive against unexpected output
The commit should not trigger a release
Analyzing commit: Refactor sqlcmd wrapper for better error handling
Previously this code used the `-o output_file` option. This caused both
query output and warnings/errors to be mixed together in a single file,
which then required hairy and error prone code to try to separate back
out.

We now just let sqlcmd write to stdout, which we redirect to a file
ourselves, leaving error output written to stderr.

Closes #239
The commit should not trigger a release
Analyzing commit: Test that SQL runtime errors are handled correctly
The commit should not trigger a release
Analyzing commit: Compare contents of files directly in tests
This makes the test failure output more useful as it shows the diff
between the files.
The commit should not trigger a release
Analysis of 5 commits complete: no release
```

I think this is because the merge commit looks like this and doesn't contain "fix:" as its first characters:
```
Merge pull request #240 from opensafely/sqlcmd-improvements
fix: Refactor sqlcmd wrapper for better error handling
```

Ideally the PR check and the action would agree about what constitutes an appropriately annotated PR.

comment.body:
The semantic-pull-requests GitHub app has [long been deprecated](https://github.com/zeke/semantic-pull-requests/commit/b67529a2d661a5c3965cfed2eafe2bd8173fd108), so we're no longer using it here anyway.

But the original issue still stands, so I renamed the issue. The issue is with github-tag-action which still doesn't support PR titles, only the start of commit messages.

issue.title: Enable site preview for Dependabot builds
issue.body:
We're now building the site via GitHub Actions and pushing that to Cloudflare Pages ourselves to deploy the site, following #921.

This requires secrets to deploy. Dependabot does not have access to these secrets (#929). #930 simply skips the publish step for Dependabot PRs, which means you don't get an automatic preview. This isn't too big a problem as most changes are likely fairly innocuous, provided the site builds.

If we want to resolve it, we would either need to: 

* use `pull_request_target` as the workflow trigger (which has [security implications](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-preventing-pwn-requests/) which we would be better avoiding)
* or (probably better) separating build and deploy steps by building the site and uploading artifacts in one workflow, then triggering deployment of those artifacts via `workflow_run`, with secrets access.

Alternatively, if Cloudflare Pages ever improves to allow builds with newer Python, we could consider allowing Cloudflare Pages to do the build and deploy. This removes this problem.

comment.body: Another option is to provide [Dependabot with its own secret](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/dependabot/working-with-dependabot/managing-encrypted-secrets-for-dependabot).

issue.title: Update screenshots regularly

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
# Summary

As mentioned by @ghickman on Slack, we could use something like [shot-scraper](https://github.com/simonw/shot-scraper) to generate screenshots.

This ideally would be automated or, failing that, semi-automated and run by a developer locally.

## Benefits

Inspired by https://twitter.com/aaronbassett/status/1536708194160070658:

* For users, this keeps screenshots up-to-date with the current appearance of web services.
* For developers, these act as simple additional checks, warning us when web services have changed substantially, either when:
  * the layout has changed somewhat, and a new screenshot does not represent what was intended
  * the layout has changed enough that this automation fails

## Questions/ideas

* What's the best way of automating login to external services where necessary?
  * Relevant issue for shot-scraper: https://github.com/simonw/shot-scraper/issues/30
  * Can we configure 2FA for such services to secure test accounts? This seems a little tricky.
* Would some services block GitHub Actions runners? I've seen this when automating link checks.
* For services that we develop, we should probably run them with a GitHub Actions runner to screenshot, instead of trying to login into the production site.
* What about screenshots of, for example, Docker or GitHub Desktop installation processes?
* Do we want to image diff and use that in automation, to determine when to update?

comment.body:
Another problem: annotating screenshots where they have extra labelling. Example: https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/blob/bd84ebf8bc0dd0b9f86fa782bba2fbb94b9b4538/docs/images/adding-codelist-id-tag.png

The current route via shot-scraper is clunky, though there's an [open issue](https://github.com/simonw/shot-scraper/issues/9) to improve it.

pull_request.title: build(deps): bump pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish from 1.6.1 to 1.6.4
pull_request.body:
Bumps [pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish](https://github.com/pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish) from 1.6.1 to 1.6.4.
Release notes

Sourced from pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish's releases.

v1.6.4

oh, boi! again?

This is the last one tonight, promise! It fixes this embarrassing bug that was actually caught by the CI but got overlooked due to the lack of sleep. TL;DR GH passed $HOME from the external env into the container and that tricked the Python's site module to think that the home directory is elsewhere, adding non-existent paths to the env vars. See #115.

Full Diff: https://github.com/pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish/compare/v1.6.3...v1.6.4

v1.6.3

Another Release!? Why?

In pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish#112, it was discovered that passing a $PATH variable even breaks the shebang. So this version adds more safeguards to make sure it keeps working with a fully broken $PATH.

Full Diff: https://github.com/pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish/compare/v1.6.2...v1.6.3

v1.6.2

What's Fixed

  • Made the $PATH and $PYTHONPATH environment variables resilient to broken values passed from the host runner environment, which previously allowed the users to accidentally break the container's internal runtime as reported in pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish#112

Internal Maintenance Improvements

  • Added a devpi-based smoke-test GitHub Actions CI/CD workflow by @​sesdaile-varmour in pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish#111

New Contributors

  • @​sesdaile-varmour made their first contribution in pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish#111

Full Diff: https://github.com/pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish/compare/v1.6.1...v1.6.2

Commits
  • c7f29f7 🐛 Override $HOME in the container with /root
  • 644926c 🧪 Always run smoke testing in debug mode
  • e71a4a4 Add support for verbose bash execusion w/ $DEBUG
  • e56e821 🐛 Make id always available in twine-upload
  • c879b84 🐛 Use full path to bash in shebang
  • 57e7d53 🐛Ensure the default $PATH value is pre-loaded
  • ce291dc 🎨🐛Fix the branch @ pre-commit.ci badge links
  • 102d8ab 🐛 Rehardcode devpi port for GHA srv container
  • 3a9eaef 🐛Use different ports in/out of GHA containers
  • a01fa74 🐛 Use localhost @ GHA outside the containers
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

pull_request.title: build(deps-dev): bump pip-tools from 6.9.0 to 6.11.0
pull_request.body:
Bumps [pip-tools](https://github.com/jazzband/pip-tools) from 6.9.0 to 6.11.0.
Release notes

Sourced from pip-tools's releases.

6.11.0

Features:

  • Add pyproject.toml file (#1643). Thanks @​otherJL0
  • Support build isolation using setuptools/pyproject.toml requirement files (#1727). Thanks @​atugushev

Bug Fixes:

  • Improve punctuation/grammar with pip-compile header (#1547). Thanks @​blueyed
  • Generate hashes for all available candidates (#1723). Thanks @​neykov

Other Changes:

  • Bump click minimum version to >= 8 (#1733). Thanks @​atugushev
  • Bump pip minimum version to >= 22.2 (#1729). Thanks @​atugushev

6.10.0

Features:

  • Deprecate pip-compile --resolver=legacy (#1724). Thanks @​atugushev
  • Prompt user to use the backtracking resolver on errors (#1719). Thanks @​maxfenv
  • Add support for Python 3.11 final (#1708). Thanks @​hugovk
  • Add --newline=[LF|CRLF|native|preserve] option to pip-compile (#1652). Thanks @​AndydeCleyre

Bug Fixes:

  • Fix inconsistent handling of constraints comments with backtracking resolver (#1713). Thanks @​mkniewallner
  • Fix some encoding warnings in Python 3.10 (PEP 597) (#1614). Thanks @​GalaxySnail

Other Changes:

  • Update pip-tools version in the README's pre-commit examples (#1701). Thanks @​Kludex
  • Document use of the backtracking resolver (#1718). Thanks @​maxfenv
  • Use HTTPS in a readme link (#1716). Thanks @​Arhell
Changelog

Sourced from pip-tools's changelog.

6.11.0 (2022-11-30)

  • Add pyproject.toml file (#1643). Thanks @​otherJL0

  • Generate hashes for all available candidates (#1723). Thanks @​neykov

Other Changes:

  • Bump click minimum version to >= 8 (#1733). Thanks @​atugushev
  • Bump pip minimum version to >= 22.2 (#1729). Thanks @​atugushev

6.10.0 (2022-11-13)

Features:

  • Deprecate pip-compile --resolver=legacy (#1724). Thanks @​atugushev
  • Prompt user to use the backtracking resolver on errors (#1719). Thanks @​maxfenv
  • Add support for Python 3.11 final (#1708). Thanks @​hugovk
  • Add --newline=[LF|CRLF|native|preserve] option to pip-compile (#1652). Thanks @​AndydeCleyre

Bug Fixes:

  • Fix inconsistent handling of constraints comments with backtracking resolver (#1713). Thanks @​mkniewallner
  • Fix some encoding warnings in Python 3.10 (PEP 597) (#1614). Thanks @​GalaxySnail

Other Changes:

  • Update pip-tools version in the README's pre-commit examples (#1701). Thanks @​Kludex
  • Document use of the backtracking resolver (#1718). Thanks @​maxfenv
  • Use HTTPS in a readme link (#1716).

pull_request.title: build(deps-dev): bump sqlalchemy from 1.4.43 to 1.4.44
pull_request.body:
Bumps [sqlalchemy](https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy) from 1.4.43 to 1.4.44.
Release notes

Sourced from sqlalchemy's releases.

1.4.44

Released: November 12, 2022

sql

  • [sql] [bug] Fixed critical memory issue identified in cache key generation, where for very large and complex ORM statements that make use of lots of ORM aliases with subqueries, cache key generation could produce excessively large keys that were orders of magnitude bigger than the statement itself. Much thanks to Rollo Konig Brock for their very patient, long term help in finally identifying this issue.

    References: #8790

postgresql

  • [postgresql] [bug] [mssql] For the PostgreSQL and SQL Server dialects only, adjusted the compiler so that when rendering column expressions in the RETURNING clause, the "non anon" label that's used in SELECT statements is suggested for SQL expression elements that generate a label; the primary example is a SQL function that may be emitting as part of the column's type, where the label name should match the column's name by default. This restores a not-well defined behavior that had changed in version 1.4.21 due to #6718, #6710. The Oracle dialect has a different RETURNING implementation and was not affected by this issue. Version 2.0 features an across the board change for its widely expanded support of RETURNING on other backends.

    References: #8770

oracle

  • [oracle] [bug] Fixed issue in the Oracle dialect where an INSERT statement that used insert(some_table).values(...).returning(some_table) against a full Table object at once would fail to execute, raising an exception.

tests

  • [tests] [bug] Fixed issue where the --disable-asyncio parameter to the test suite would fail to not actually run greenlet tests and would also not prevent the suite from using a "wrapping" greenlet for the whole suite. This parameter now ensures that no greenlet or asyncio use will occur within the entire run when set.

    References: #8793

... (truncated)

pull_request.title: build(deps-dev): bump sqlalchemy from 1.4.43 to 1.4.44
pull_request.body:
Bumps [sqlalchemy](https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy) from 1.4.43 to 1.4.44.
Release notes

Sourced from sqlalchemy's releases.

1.4.44

Released: November 12, 2022

sql

  • [sql] [bug] Fixed critical memory issue identified in cache key generation, where for very large and complex ORM statements that make use of lots of ORM aliases with subqueries, cache key generation could produce excessively large keys that were orders of magnitude bigger than the statement itself. Much thanks to Rollo Konig Brock for their very patient, long term help in finally identifying this issue.

    References: #8790

postgresql

  • [postgresql] [bug] [mssql] For the PostgreSQL and SQL Server dialects only, adjusted the compiler so that when rendering column expressions in the RETURNING clause, the "non anon" label that's used in SELECT statements is suggested for SQL expression elements that generate a label; the primary example is a SQL function that may be emitting as part of the column's type, where the label name should match the column's name by default. This restores a not-well defined behavior that had changed in version 1.4.21 due to #6718, #6710. The Oracle dialect has a different RETURNING implementation and was not affected by this issue. Version 2.0 features an across the board change for its widely expanded support of RETURNING on other backends.

    References: #8770

oracle

  • [oracle] [bug] Fixed issue in the Oracle dialect where an INSERT statement that used insert(some_table).values(...).returning(some_table) against a full Table object at once would fail to execute, raising an exception.

tests

  • [tests] [bug] Fixed issue where the --disable-asyncio parameter to the test suite would fail to not actually run greenlet tests and would also not prevent the suite from using a "wrapping" greenlet for the whole suite. This parameter now ensures that no greenlet or asyncio use will occur within the entire run when set.

    References: #8793

... (truncated)

issue.title: MSSQL Docker container doesn't run on M1 macs
issue.body:
Just a note for the future that I cannot run tests on databuilder on a M1 mac. Unit tests work fine. The docker container for MSSQL starts and then immediately stops. I have not explored this in great detail as I have the option of switching to an intel. 

Next steps:
- Other mac m1 users try to run tests that require docker to see if problem persist
- If they do, change documentation to indicate this

comment.body:
Upstream issues perhaps worth tracking:

* Microsoft: https://github.com/microsoft/mssql-docker/issues/734
* Docker: https://github.com/docker/roadmap/issues/384

The current workarounds still use colima as mentioned already in this thread.

issue.title: Too many Network errors: Looking for suggestions

labels.name: question
labels.description: Further information is requested

issue.body:
Hey folks, Have been tinkering with Lychee lately to run on static HTML and check about 17k+ links. From those, I am getting about 400+ links resulting in a Network error. I wanted to open an issue here to ask folks if I might be doing something wrong or if something can be improved to mitigate these. 

- Here's my lychee report below: https://github.com/balena-io/docs/issues/2303
- GitHub action: https://github.com/balena-io/docs/blob/master/.github/workflows/link-checker.yml
- `lychee.toml` file: https://github.com/balena-io/docs/blob/master/lychee.toml 

I have set `verbose: true` I wish it could show what the actual HTTP error code is in the report that gets generated.

comment.body:
> information_source **If anyone runs into issues with rate limiting in the future, there is now a troubleshooting guide over at [lychee.cli.rs/#/rate-limits](http://lychee.cli.rs/#/rate-limits).**

> * The ordering of columns may not be consistent between the dummy data and the TPP/EMIS backend. You should avoid referring to index integer positions and instead use the index names.

comment.body: Fixed by #490.

issue.title: Improve documentation for installing docker on Windows Home

labels.name: improve content
labels.description: Improve existing documentation content

issue.body:
This is what the [official docs](https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-windows/install-windows-home/) have to say:


* Hyper-V and Containers Windows features must be enabled.
* The following hardware prerequisites are required to successfully run Client Hyper-V on Windows 10:
  * 64 bit processor with Second Level Address Translation (SLAT)
  * 4GB system RAM
  * BIOS-level hardware virtualization support must be enabled in the BIOS settings. For more information, see Virtualization.


Our test user has a "very late" build of Windows 10 Home: they went through the requirements trying to find out if they had SLAT.  They added:

> I  couldn’t get the virtualization stuff to work either.
>
> There were a series of more & more complex things for a simpleton like me to do with Hyper-V and Containers Windows. I also enabled WSL1 but didn’t get WSL2 to go.
>
> I don’t know if I was close to getting it going, but each time I got something, I found there was another 2 levels to negotiate.

comment.body:
Windows Home doesn't have Hyper-V support.

But installation on Windows Home should be simpler now: Windows Home does support WSL2 and WSL2 is now the default recommendation from Docker for Docker Desktop. You do still require hardware that supports virtualisation (in other words, Intel VT-x or AMD-V), and that feature to be enabled in the BIOS, if it isn't by default.

issue.title: Integrate data ingestion dates

labels.name: new content
labels.description: New documentation content

issue.body:
Somehow, we want to get the information from [this notebook](https://github.com/opensafely/rapid-reports/blob/master/notebooks/latest-dates.ipynb) into the documentation.

The simplest iteration is to confirm we are allow to publish it without NHSE approval; then link to it from the docs.

The better iteration is to convert the notebook into a project pipeline (this will also require study definition support for querying build time metadata from the backend); get it to output the result as markdown, and write that directly to this repo (via a PR).

comment.body:
@sebbacon: Reviewing this old issue, the current state is:

* the new-since-this-issue-was-originally-opened reports site contains the [database report](https://reports.opensafely.org/reports/opensafely-tpp-database-builds/)
* the [documentation site](https://docs.opensafely.org/data-sources/systmone/#opensafely-tpp-database-coverage-and-metadata) links to the database report

Is there anything else needed here? Would we still want to integrate this data more tightly into the docs site?

    •

issue.title: Long codelist filename in acceptance test can prevent `pip install` on Windows
issue.body:
@benbc in https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/issues/999:

> Installing the Python package may not work on Windows. For the researcher I was working with it resulted in a too-long-file-path (trying to unpack the file `tests/acceptance/comparative_booster_study/codelists/opensafely-covid-identification-in-primary-care-suspected-covid-nonspecific-clinical-assessment.csv` into `C:\Users\lsh1803144\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-install-eneil7vg\opensafely-databuilder_edf74569c16147e8ad6b040d32231f7d`).

This is due to a [Windows limit](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/maximum-file-path-limitation) [that has bitten us before](https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/discussions/316). The length here is just a little over the limit. 

There are several ways that you can use to help work around the issue, but are clunky:

* use `subst` or Powershell `PSDrive` to get a location that points somewhere on disk to give a shorter path (the ultimate destination directory may also be an issue here).
* download the source zip and delete the tests, then `pip install` the directory

The way to run Data Builder should eventually be via `opensafely`, but mentioning this anyway.

comment.body:
I originally included the `pip install` route because it was the only way that worked at the time. Fortunately, now we can run dataset definitions via `opensafely`, thanks to Dave, and `opensafely` is now the recommended route :+1:

There's only one reason I can conceive of to retain `pip install`. This is when someone wants to try out ehrQL and work through tutorials, but they can't install Docker either because of:

* technical installation issues (Docker won't install on the hardware, but I think this is *possibly* slightly better than it used to be maybe a couple of years ago) :computer::hammer: 
* and/or business/IT policy issues (someone can't get approval for Docker because of IT security or licensing policies) :no_good:

How useful that would be, without the rest of OpenSAFELY CLI, I'm not sure :thinking: Probably the better route in these situations is ultimately Codespaces. [^1]

That point aside, I'm happy to drop the mention of `pip install` the docs. It does remove the decision making on the part of a user. So, if that's the decision here, please:

1. Close this issue as "not planned".
2. And then open an issue in the docs to remove the `pip install` route.

[^1]: We previously used Gitpod for this because it was the only viable option, but it reminds me that [we should look at and document Codespaces if it's suitable](https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/issues/1046).

issue.title: Review whether backtick snippets are generated by snex or entered manually in Markdown

labels.name: cohort extractor
labels.description: Cohort extractor-related documentation issues

labels.name: data builder
labels.description: Data Builder-related documentation issues

issue.body:
*Originally in [Shortcut](https://app.shortcut.com/ebm-datalab/story/648/review-whether-backticks-are-generated-by-snex-or-entered-manually-in-markdown); placing here so it's not lost.*

The current approach for code snippets uses the snex package. By default, this has a template that generates the backticks required in Markdown.

One limitation is that Material for MkDocs allows some [nice enhanced formatting options](https://squidfunk.github.io/mkdocs-material/reference/code-blocks/) by customising the backtick line. That is, not just specifying the language of the code block, but:

* code highlighting
* providing a code block title
* customising line numbering

There is some limited support for user provided parameters in the snex templating. But this templating might not be flexible enough to configure these features:

* snex does escaping of certain characters, such as the `"` needed in specifying line numbering. So we can't just specify "write the whole backtick ilne in the `#snippet` line before a code example".
* Sometimes these features would be wanted, at other times, not. So we can't work around the escaping of characters by including the escaped character in the template.

Note that:

* We are occasionally using these features in some existing OpenSAFELY documentation examples.
* There could be other future Material for MkDocs formatting features that we would like to use.
* There is also a "code annotations" feature that doesn't use the backtick syntax, that should also be investigated.

We should review:

1. Whether we can customise snex's templating to workaround this. This would be nicer in that the formatting is stored with the snippets. But it may not be possible.
2. Whether we should go for plain inclusion of snippets. This separates some formatting from the content, but would support anything that Material for MkDocs allows.

issue.title: Unpin black installation

labels.name: data builder
labels.description: Data Builder-related documentation issues

issue.body:
This was pinned in #885; it should be unpinned when possible.

It depends on the version of click used in [snex](https://github.com/jwbargsten/snex): we need snex to upgrade to a version of click that is also compatible with the current versions of black.

issue.title: Migrate from snex to PyMdown snippet support

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: data builder
labels.description: Data Builder-related documentation issues

issue.body:
Will resolve #886 by removing the extra snex dependency.

https://facelessuser.github.io/pymdown-extensions/extensions/snippets/#snippet-sections

commits.message: Remove snex requirement

Unpin `black` and `click` dependencies

Fixes #886.

Remove `examples/` directory

This contains snippets processed by snex.

With PyMdown, we will just use the snippets directly.

Upgrade `pymdown-extensions` to 9.9

To support snippet sections:

https://facelessuser.github.io/pymdown-extensions/extensions/snippets/#specifying-snippet-locations
Move snippets to use PyMdown syntax
Fix whitespace in files
Remove unused sections of snippets

Replace `extract` with `test` recipe

We no longer need `extract` as we don't use snex. There is no "build
examples from snippets" step with PyMdown.

Remove `watch-examples` recipe

It is not needed as PyMdown automatically processes the snippet
sections. There is no extra step of generating the files to include from
the snippets, unlike with snex.

Update snippet documentation

Following removal of snex.

Merge pull request #1044 from opensafely/steve/use-pymdown-snippets

Use PyMdown snippets support

pull_request.title: Use PyMdown snippets support
pull_request.body:
Fixes #1015, fixes #886, fixes #735.

Use the new PyMdown snippets support in place of snex.

snex:

* is an additional dependency (we require PyMdown anyway)
* doesn't appear to be regularly maintained (resulting in the problem of #886)
* has an intermediate build step for the snippets (an extra complication)

One slight downside is that the names of snippets sections don't seem to be able to have any way of [including characters that indicate word breaks](https://github.com/facelessuser/pymdown-extensions/blob/22fe9c93c76d477665eb0377ca9871da7362b41f/pymdownx/snippets.py#L66-L73) (for examples, spaces, hyphens or underscores), but the big upside is that we drop snex.

issue.title: Specify `site_url` in MkDocs configuration for correct sitemap
issue.body:
Fixes #1053.

To correctly generate the `sitemap.xml`, the [`site_url` must be specified in `mkdocs.yml`](https://github.com/mkdocs/mkdocs/issues/1783).

Having a valid sitemap can help search engines [index a site's content](https://developers.google.com/search/docs/crawling-indexing/sitemaps/overview).

What I've done here is to make `site_url` switchable depending on an environment variable, `MKDOCS_SITE_URL` and then simply set that on build. As this is only really required for deployment, I've just put this in the deployment workflow, instead of adding some wrapper or to do the build with the environment variable supplied.

This keeps the local development setup exactly as it was, with no value set for `site_url`.

I'm reasonably convinced that this is the right approach because:

* we can override the `site_url`
  * to set as an empty string if we ever want to build a [local file distribution](https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/deploying-your-docs/#local-files) (this may not be necessary with a missing value, but not tested)
  * when running locally with no URL set, the configuration is as it was previously (although I think with `mkdocs serve`, the site URL is ignored anyway!)
* we probably do want the canonical URL to be `https://docs.opensafely.org/some-path…` even for Cloudflare test deployments, technically

comment.body:
> I'm reasonably convinced that this is the right approach…

…but am happy to be persuaded otherwise, that, for instance, we should only set `site_url` for actual production deployments to the site (and not for other Cloudflare Pages previews that we get)

issue.title: `sitemap.xml` not correctly generated for production site

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

issue.body:
Locally, it works:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<urlset xmlns="http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9">
    <url>
         <loc>http://127.0.0.1:8000/</loc>
         <lastmod>2022-12-08</lastmod>
         <changefreq>daily</changefreq>
    </url>
    <url>
         <loc>http://127.0.0.1:8000/access-policies/</loc>
         <lastmod>2022-12-08</lastmod>
         <changefreq>daily</changefreq>
    </url>
…
```

But on the [production site](https://docs.opensafely.org/sitemap.xml),

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<urlset xmlns="http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9">
    <url>
         <loc>None</loc>
         <lastmod>2022-12-08</lastmod>
         <changefreq>daily</changefreq>
    </url>
    <url>
         <loc>None</loc>
         <lastmod>2022-12-08</lastmod>
         <changefreq>daily</changefreq>
    </url>
…
```

The fix is to specify `site_url: https://docs.opensafely.org` in `mkdocs.yml`.

However, I'm not sure we want this setting globally: strictly speaking, for local development and temporary Cloudflare PR, the site URL is different.

It is possible to [customise this, as I previously mentioned](https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/pull/327#issuecomment-883324756); I hadn't realised that this issue broke the sitemap.

issue.title: Add structure to URLs of databuilder docs

labels.name: data builder
labels.description: Data Builder-related documentation issues

issue.body:
The URL structure of the OpenSAFELY documentation is currently flat.  It would be neater (and would make the docs source code easier to navigate) if the URLs were nested.  For instance:

| old | new |
|-|-|
| https://docs.opensafely.org/data-builder-toc/ | https://docs.opensafely.org/data-builder/ |
| https://docs.opensafely.org/ehrql-intro/ | https://docs.opensafely.org/data-builder/ehrql/ |
| https://docs.opensafely.org/ehrql-tutorial/ | https://docs.opensafely.org/data-builder/ehrql/tutorial/ |

We can start with the databuilder (or is it data-builder?) docs since these are unused and we don't have to worry about redirects.

issue.title: Semantic prefixes in PR titles don't trigger a release
issue.body:
By pre-pending "fix:" to [this PR](https://github.com/opensafely/cohort-extractor/pull/240) title, the PR passed the [semantic-pull-requests check](https://github.com/zeke/semantic-pull-requests).

However when merged it didn't then trigger a new release:
```
Analyzing commit: Merge pull request #240 from opensafely/sqlcmd-improvements
fix: Refactor sqlcmd wrapper for better error handling
The commit should not trigger a release
Analyzing commit: Be slightly more defensive against unexpected output
The commit should not trigger a release
Analyzing commit: Refactor sqlcmd wrapper for better error handling
Previously this code used the `-o output_file` option. This caused both
query output and warnings/errors to be mixed together in a single file,
which then required hairy and error prone code to try to separate back
out.

We now just let sqlcmd write to stdout, which we redirect to a file
ourselves, leaving error output written to stderr.

Closes #239
The commit should not trigger a release
Analyzing commit: Test that SQL runtime errors are handled correctly
The commit should not trigger a release
Analyzing commit: Compare contents of files directly in tests
This makes the test failure output more useful as it shows the diff
between the files.
The commit should not trigger a release
Analysis of 5 commits complete: no release
```

I think this is because the merge commit looks like this and doesn't contain "fix:" as its first characters:
```
Merge pull request #240 from opensafely/sqlcmd-improvements
fix: Refactor sqlcmd wrapper for better error handling
```

Ideally the PR check and the action would agree about what constitutes an appropriately annotated PR.

comment.body:
The semantic-pull-requests GitHub app has [long been deprecated](https://github.com/zeke/semantic-pull-requests/commit/b67529a2d661a5c3965cfed2eafe2bd8173fd108), so we're no longer using it here anyway.

But the original issue still stands, so I renamed the issue. The issue is with github-tag-action which still doesn't support PR titles, only the start of commit messages.

issue.title: Enable site preview for Dependabot builds
issue.body:
We're now building the site via GitHub Actions and pushing that to Cloudflare Pages ourselves to deploy the site, following #921.

This requires secrets to deploy. Dependabot does not have access to these secrets (#929). #930 simply skips the publish step for Dependabot PRs, which means you don't get an automatic preview. This isn't too big a problem as most changes are likely fairly innocuous, provided the site builds.

If we want to resolve it, we would either need to: 

* use `pull_request_target` as the workflow trigger (which has [security implications](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-preventing-pwn-requests/) which we would be better avoiding)
* or (probably better) separating build and deploy steps by building the site and uploading artifacts in one workflow, then triggering deployment of those artifacts via `workflow_run`, with secrets access.

Alternatively, if Cloudflare Pages ever improves to allow builds with newer Python, we could consider allowing Cloudflare Pages to do the build and deploy. This removes this problem.

comment.body: Another option is to provide [Dependabot with its own secret](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/dependabot/working-with-dependabot/managing-encrypted-secrets-for-dependabot).

issue.title: Update screenshots regularly

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
# Summary

As mentioned by @ghickman on Slack, we could use something like [shot-scraper](https://github.com/simonw/shot-scraper) to generate screenshots.

This ideally would be automated or, failing that, semi-automated and run by a developer locally.

## Benefits

Inspired by https://twitter.com/aaronbassett/status/1536708194160070658:

* For users, this keeps screenshots up-to-date with the current appearance of web services.
* For developers, these act as simple additional checks, warning us when web services have changed substantially, either when:
  * the layout has changed somewhat, and a new screenshot does not represent what was intended
  * the layout has changed enough that this automation fails

## Questions/ideas

* What's the best way of automating login to external services where necessary?
  * Relevant issue for shot-scraper: https://github.com/simonw/shot-scraper/issues/30
  * Can we configure 2FA for such services to secure test accounts? This seems a little tricky.
* Would some services block GitHub Actions runners? I've seen this when automating link checks.
* For services that we develop, we should probably run them with a GitHub Actions runner to screenshot, instead of trying to login into the production site.
* What about screenshots of, for example, Docker or GitHub Desktop installation processes?
* Do we want to image diff and use that in automation, to determine when to update?

comment.body:
Another problem: annotating screenshots where they have extra labelling. Example: https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/blob/bd84ebf8bc0dd0b9f86fa782bba2fbb94b9b4538/docs/images/adding-codelist-id-tag.png

The current route via shot-scraper is clunky, though there's an [open issue](https://github.com/simonw/shot-scraper/issues/9) to improve it.

pull_request.title: build(deps): bump pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish from 1.6.1 to 1.6.4
pull_request.body:
Bumps [pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish](https://github.com/pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish) from 1.6.1 to 1.6.4.
Release notes

Sourced from pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish's releases.

v1.6.4

oh, boi! again?

This is the last one tonight, promise! It fixes this embarrassing bug that was actually caught by the CI but got overlooked due to the lack of sleep. TL;DR GH passed $HOME from the external env into the container and that tricked the Python's site module to think that the home directory is elsewhere, adding non-existent paths to the env vars. See #115.

Full Diff: https://github.com/pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish/compare/v1.6.3...v1.6.4

v1.6.3

Another Release!? Why?

In pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish#112, it was discovered that passing a $PATH variable even breaks the shebang. So this version adds more safeguards to make sure it keeps working with a fully broken $PATH.

Full Diff: https://github.com/pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish/compare/v1.6.2...v1.6.3

v1.6.2

What's Fixed

  • Made the $PATH and $PYTHONPATH environment variables resilient to broken values passed from the host runner environment, which previously allowed the users to accidentally break the container's internal runtime as reported in pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish#112

Internal Maintenance Improvements

  • Added a devpi-based smoke-test GitHub Actions CI/CD workflow by @​sesdaile-varmour in pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish#111

New Contributors

  • @​sesdaile-varmour made their first contribution in pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish#111

Full Diff: https://github.com/pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish/compare/v1.6.1...v1.6.2

Commits
  • c7f29f7 🐛 Override $HOME in the container with /root
  • 644926c 🧪 Always run smoke testing in debug mode
  • e71a4a4 Add support for verbose bash execusion w/ $DEBUG
  • e56e821 🐛 Make id always available in twine-upload
  • c879b84 🐛 Use full path to bash in shebang
  • 57e7d53 🐛Ensure the default $PATH value is pre-loaded
  • ce291dc 🎨🐛Fix the branch @ pre-commit.ci badge links
  • 102d8ab 🐛 Rehardcode devpi port for GHA srv container
  • 3a9eaef 🐛Use different ports in/out of GHA containers
  • a01fa74 🐛 Use localhost @ GHA outside the containers
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

pull_request.title: build(deps-dev): bump pip-tools from 6.9.0 to 6.11.0
pull_request.body:
Bumps [pip-tools](https://github.com/jazzband/pip-tools) from 6.9.0 to 6.11.0.
Release notes

Sourced from pip-tools's releases.

6.11.0

Features:

  • Add pyproject.toml file (#1643). Thanks @​otherJL0
  • Support build isolation using setuptools/pyproject.toml requirement files (#1727). Thanks @​atugushev

Bug Fixes:

  • Improve punctuation/grammar with pip-compile header (#1547). Thanks @​blueyed
  • Generate hashes for all available candidates (#1723). Thanks @​neykov

Other Changes:

  • Bump click minimum version to >= 8 (#1733). Thanks @​atugushev
  • Bump pip minimum version to >= 22.2 (#1729). Thanks @​atugushev

6.10.0

Features:

  • Deprecate pip-compile --resolver=legacy (#1724). Thanks @​atugushev
  • Prompt user to use the backtracking resolver on errors (#1719). Thanks @​maxfenv
  • Add support for Python 3.11 final (#1708). Thanks @​hugovk
  • Add --newline=[LF|CRLF|native|preserve] option to pip-compile (#1652). Thanks @​AndydeCleyre

Bug Fixes:

  • Fix inconsistent handling of constraints comments with backtracking resolver (#1713). Thanks @​mkniewallner
  • Fix some encoding warnings in Python 3.10 (PEP 597) (#1614). Thanks @​GalaxySnail

Other Changes:

  • Update pip-tools version in the README's pre-commit examples (#1701). Thanks @​Kludex
  • Document use of the backtracking resolver (#1718). Thanks @​maxfenv
  • Use HTTPS in a readme link (#1716). Thanks @​Arhell
Changelog

Sourced from pip-tools's changelog.

6.11.0 (2022-11-30)

Features:

  • Add pyproject.toml file (#1643). Thanks @​otherJL0
  • Support build isolation using setuptools/pyproject.toml requirement files (#1727). Thanks @​atugushev

Bug Fixes:

Other Changes:

  • Bump click minimum version to >= 8 (#1733). Thanks @​atugushev
  • Bump pip minimum version to >= 22.2 (#1729). Thanks @​atugushev

6.10.0 (2022-11-13)

Features:

  • Deprecate pip-compile --resolver=legacy (#1724). Thanks @​atugushev
  • Prompt user to use the backtracking resolver on errors (#1719). Thanks @​maxfenv
  • Add support for Python 3.11 final (#1708). Thanks @​hugovk

pull_request.title: build(deps-dev): bump sqlalchemy from 1.4.43 to 1.4.44
pull_request.body:
Bumps [sqlalchemy](https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy) from 1.4.43 to 1.4.44.
Release notes

Sourced from sqlalchemy's releases.

1.4.44

Released: November 12, 2022

sql

  • [sql] [bug] Fixed critical memory issue identified in cache key generation, where for very large and complex ORM statements that make use of lots of ORM aliases with subqueries, cache key generation could produce excessively large keys that were orders of magnitude bigger than the statement itself. Much thanks to Rollo Konig Brock for their very patient, long term help in finally identifying this issue.

    References: #8790

postgresql

  • [postgresql] [bug] [mssql] For the PostgreSQL and SQL Server dialects only, adjusted the compiler so that when rendering column expressions in the RETURNING clause, the "non anon" label that's used in SELECT statements is suggested for SQL expression elements that generate a label; the primary example is a SQL function that may be emitting as part of the column's type, where the label name should match the column's name by default. This restores a not-well defined behavior that had changed in version 1.4.21 due to #6718, #6710. The Oracle dialect has a different RETURNING implementation and was not affected by this issue. Version 2.0 features an across the board change for its widely expanded support of RETURNING on other backends.

    References: #8770

oracle

  • [oracle] [bug] Fixed issue in the Oracle dialect where an INSERT statement that used insert(some_table).values(...).returning(some_table) against a full Table object at once would fail to execute, raising an exception.

tests

  • [tests] [bug] Fixed issue where the --disable-asyncio parameter to the test suite would fail to not actually run greenlet tests and would also not prevent the suite from using a "wrapping" greenlet for the whole suite. This parameter now ensures that no greenlet or asyncio use will occur within the entire run when set.

    References: #8793

... (truncated)

Commits

issue.title: MSSQL Docker container doesn't run on M1 macs
issue.body:
Just a note for the future that I cannot run tests on databuilder on a M1 mac. Unit tests work fine. The docker container for MSSQL starts and then immediately stops. I have not explored this in great detail as I have the option of switching to an intel. 

Next steps:
- Other mac m1 users try to run tests that require docker to see if problem persist
- If they do, change documentation to indicate this

comment.body:
Upstream issues perhaps worth tracking:

* Microsoft: https://github.com/microsoft/mssql-docker/issues/734
* Docker: https://github.com/docker/roadmap/issues/384

The current workarounds still use colima as mentioned already in this thread.

issue.title: Too many Network errors: Looking for suggestions

labels.name: question
labels.description: Further information is requested

issue.body:
Hey folks, Have been tinkering with Lychee lately to run on static HTML and check about 17k+ links. From those, I am getting about 400+ links resulting in a Network error. I wanted to open an issue here to ask folks if I might be doing something wrong or if something can be improved to mitigate these. 

- Here's my lychee report below: https://github.com/balena-io/docs/issues/2303
- GitHub action: https://github.com/balena-io/docs/blob/master/.github/workflows/link-checker.yml
- `lychee.toml` file: https://github.com/balena-io/docs/blob/master/lychee.toml 

I have set `verbose: true` I wish it could show what the actual HTTP error code is in the report that gets generated.

comment.body:
> information_source **If anyone runs into issues with rate limiting in the future, there is now a troubleshooting guide over at [lychee.cli.rs/#/rate-limits](http://lychee.cli.rs/#/rate-limits).**

The rate limit troubleshooting guide moved to: https://lychee.cli.rs/#/troubleshooting/rate-limits

comment.body: Fixed by #490.

issue.title: Improve documentation for installing docker on Windows Home

labels.name: improve content
labels.description: Improve existing documentation content

issue.body:
This is what the [official docs](https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-windows/install-windows-home/) have to say:


* Hyper-V and Containers Windows features must be enabled.
* The following hardware prerequisites are required to successfully run Client Hyper-V on Windows 10:
  * 64 bit processor with Second Level Address Translation (SLAT)
  * 4GB system RAM
  * BIOS-level hardware virtualization support must be enabled in the BIOS settings. For more information, see Virtualization.


Our test user has a "very late" build of Windows 10 Home: they went through the requirements trying to find out if they had SLAT.  They added:

> I  couldn’t get the virtualization stuff to work either.
>
> There were a series of more & more complex things for a simpleton like me to do with Hyper-V and Containers Windows. I also enabled WSL1 but didn’t get WSL2 to go.
>
> I don’t know if I was close to getting it going, but each time I got something, I found there was another 2 levels to negotiate.

comment.body:
Windows Home doesn't have Hyper-V support.

But installation on Windows Home should be simpler now: Windows Home does support WSL2 and WSL2 is now the default recommendation from Docker for Docker Desktop. You do still require hardware that supports virtualisation (in other words, Intel VT-x or AMD-V), and that feature to be enabled in the BIOS, if it isn't by default.

issue.title: Integrate data ingestion dates

labels.name: new content
labels.description: New documentation content

issue.body:
Somehow, we want to get the information from [this notebook](https://github.com/opensafely/rapid-reports/blob/master/notebooks/latest-dates.ipynb) into the documentation.

The simplest iteration is to confirm we are allow to publish it without NHSE approval; then link to it from the docs.

The better iteration is to convert the notebook into a project pipeline (this will also require study definition support for querying build time metadata from the backend); get it to output the result as markdown, and write that directly to this repo (via a PR).

comment.body:
@sebbacon: Reviewing this old issue, the current state is:

* the new-since-this-issue-was-originally-opened reports site contains the [database report](https://reports.opensafely.org/reports/opensafely-tpp-database-builds/)
* the [documentation site](https://docs.opensafely.org/data-sources/systmone/#opensafely-tpp-database-coverage-and-metadata) links to the database report

Is there anything else needed here? Would we still want to integrate this data more tightly into the docs site?

issue.title: Long codelist filename in acceptance test can prevent `pip install` on Windows
issue.body:
@benbc in https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/issues/999:

> Installing the Python package may not work on Windows. For the researcher I was working with it resulted in a too-long-file-path (trying to unpack the file `tests/acceptance/comparative_booster_study/codelists/opensafely-covid-identification-in-primary-care-suspected-covid-nonspecific-clinical-assessment.csv` into `C:\Users\lsh1803144\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-install-eneil7vg\opensafely-databuilder_edf74569c16147e8ad6b040d32231f7d`).

This is due to a [Windows limit](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/maximum-file-path-limitation) [that has bitten us before](https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/discussions/316). The length here is just a little over the limit. 

There are several ways that you can use to help work around the issue, but are clunky:

* use `subst` or Powershell `PSDrive` to get a location that points somewhere on disk to give a shorter path (the ultimate destination directory may also be an issue here).
* download the source zip and delete the tests, then `pip install` the directory

The way to run Data Builder should eventually be via `opensafely`, but mentioning this anyway.

comment.body:
I originally included the `pip install` route because it was the only way that worked at the time. Fortunately, now we can run dataset definitions via `opensafely`, thanks to Dave, and `opensafely` is now the recommended route :+1:

There's only one reason I can conceive of to retain `pip install`. This is when someone wants to try out ehrQL and work through tutorials, but they can't install Docker either because of:

* technical installation issues (Docker won't install on the hardware, but I think this is *possibly* slightly better than it used to be maybe a couple of years ago) :computer::hammer: 
* and/or business/IT policy issues (someone can't get approval for Docker because of IT security or licensing policies) :no_good:

How useful that would be, without the rest of OpenSAFELY CLI, I'm not sure :thinking: Probably the better route in these situations is ultimately Codespaces. [^1]

That point aside, I'm happy to drop the mention of `pip install` the docs. It does remove the decision making on the part of a user. So, if that's the decision here, please:

1. Close this issue as "not planned".
2. And then open an issue in the docs to remove the `pip install` route.

[^1]: We previously used Gitpod for this because it was the only viable option, but it reminds me that [we should look at and document Codespaces if it's suitable](https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/issues/1046).

issue.title: Review whether backtick snippets are generated by snex or entered manually in Markdown

labels.name: cohort extractor
labels.description: Cohort extractor-related documentation issues

labels.name: data builder
labels.description: Data Builder-related documentation issues

issue.body:
*Originally in [Shortcut](https://app.shortcut.com/ebm-datalab/story/648/review-whether-backticks-are-generated-by-snex-or-entered-manually-in-markdown); placing here so it's not lost.*

The current approach for code snippets uses the snex package. By default, this has a template that generates the backticks required in Markdown.

One limitation is that Material for MkDocs allows some [nice enhanced formatting options](https://squidfunk.github.io/mkdocs-material/reference/code-blocks/) by customising the backtick line. That is, not just specifying the language of the code block, but:

* code highlighting
* providing a code block title
* customising line numbering

There is some limited support for user provided parameters in the snex templating. But this templating might not be flexible enough to configure these features:

* snex does escaping of certain characters, such as the `"` needed in specifying line numbering. So we can't just specify "write the whole backtick ilne in the `#snippet` line before a code example".
* Sometimes these features would be wanted, at other times, not. So we can't work around the escaping of characters by including the escaped character in the template.

Note that:

* We are occasionally using these features in some existing OpenSAFELY documentation examples.
* There could be other future Material for MkDocs formatting features that we would like to use.
* There is also a "code annotations" feature that doesn't use the backtick syntax, that should also be investigated.

We should review:

1. Whether we can customise snex's templating to workaround this. This would be nicer in that the formatting is stored with the snippets. But it may not be possible.
2. Whether we should go for plain inclusion of snippets. This separates some formatting from the content, but would support anything that Material for MkDocs allows.

commits.message: Remove snex requirement

Unpin `black` and `click` dependencies

Fixes #886.

Remove `examples/` directory

This contains snippets processed by snex.

With PyMdown, we will just use the snippets directly.

Upgrade `pymdown-extensions` to 9.9

To support snippet sections:

https://facelessuser.github.io/pymdown-extensions/extensions/snippets/#specifying-snippet-locations
Move snippets to use PyMdown syntax
Fix whitespace in files
Remove unused sections of snippets

Replace `extract` with `test` recipe

We no longer need `extract` as we don't use snex. There is no "build
examples from snippets" step with PyMdown.

Remove `watch-examples` recipe

It is not needed as PyMdown automatically processes the snippet
sections. There is no extra step of generating the files to include from
the snippets, unlike with snex.

Update snippet documentation

Following removal of snex.

Merge pull request #1044 from opensafely/steve/use-pymdown-snippets

Use PyMdown snippets support

pull_request.title: Use PyMdown snippets support
pull_request.body:
Fixes #1015, fixes #886, fixes #735.

Use the new PyMdown snippets support in place of snex.

snex:

* is an additional dependency (we require PyMdown anyway)
* doesn't appear to be regularly maintained (resulting in the problem of #886)
* has an intermediate build step for the snippets (an extra complication)

One slight downside is that the names of snippets sections don't seem to be able to have any way of [including characters that indicate word breaks](https://github.com/facelessuser/pymdown-extensions/blob/22fe9c93c76d477665eb0377ca9871da7362b41f/pymdownx/snippets.py#L66-L73) (for examples, spaces, hyphens or underscores), but the big upside is that we drop snex.

issue.title: Specify `site_url` in MkDocs configuration for correct sitemap
issue.body:
Fixes #1053.

To correctly generate the `sitemap.xml`, the [`site_url` must be specified in `mkdocs.yml`](https://github.com/mkdocs/mkdocs/issues/1783).

Having a valid sitemap can help search engines [index a site's content](https://developers.google.com/search/docs/crawling-indexing/sitemaps/overview).

What I've done here is to make `site_url` switchable depending on an environment variable, `MKDOCS_SITE_URL` and then simply set that on build. As this is only really required for deployment, I've just put this in the deployment workflow, instead of adding some wrapper or to do the build with the environment variable supplied.

This keeps the local development setup exactly as it was, with no value set for `site_url`.

I'm reasonably convinced that this is the right approach because:

* we can override the `site_url`
  * to set as an empty string if we ever want to build a [local file distribution](https://www.mkdocs.org/user-guide/deploying-your-docs/#local-files) (this may not be necessary with a missing value, but not tested)
  * when running locally with no URL set, the configuration is as it was previously (although I think with `mkdocs serve`, the site URL is ignored anyway!)
* we probably do want the canonical URL to be `https://docs.opensafely.org/some-path…` even for Cloudflare test deployments, technically

comment.body:
> I'm reasonably convinced that this is the right approach…

…but am happy to be persuaded otherwise, that, for instance, we should only set `site_url` for actual production deployments to the site (and not for other Cloudflare Pages previews that we get)

Specify `site_url` in MkDocs configuration

To be able to correctly produce `sitemap.xml` and set correct canonical
link tags.

issue.title: `sitemap.xml` not correctly generated for production site

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

issue.body:
Locally, it works:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<urlset xmlns="http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9">
    <url>
         <loc>http://127.0.0.1:8000/</loc>
         <lastmod>2022-12-08</lastmod>
         <changefreq>daily</changefreq>
    </url>
    <url>
         <loc>http://127.0.0.1:8000/access-policies/</loc>
         <lastmod>2022-12-08</lastmod>
         <changefreq>daily</changefreq>
    </url>
…
```

But on the [production site](https://docs.opensafely.org/sitemap.xml),

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<urlset xmlns="http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9">
    <url>
         <loc>None</loc>
         <lastmod>2022-12-08</lastmod>
         <changefreq>daily</changefreq>
    </url>
    <url>
         <loc>None</loc>
         <lastmod>2022-12-08</lastmod>
         <changefreq>daily</changefreq>
    </url>
…
```

The fix is to specify `site_url: https://docs.opensafely.org` in `mkdocs.yml`.

However, I'm not sure we want this setting globally: strictly speaking, for local development and temporary Cloudflare PR, the site URL is different.

It is possible to [customise this, as I previously mentioned](https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/pull/327#issuecomment-883324756); I hadn't realised that this issue broke the sitemap.

issue.title: Add structure to URLs of databuilder docs

labels.name: data builder
labels.description: Data Builder-related documentation issues

issue.body:
The URL structure of the OpenSAFELY documentation is currently flat.  It would be neater (and would make the docs source code easier to navigate) if the URLs were nested.  For instance:

| old | new |
|-|-|
| https://docs.opensafely.org/data-builder-toc/ | https://docs.opensafely.org/data-builder/ |
| https://docs.opensafely.org/ehrql-intro/ | https://docs.opensafely.org/data-builder/ehrql/ |
| https://docs.opensafely.org/ehrql-tutorial/ | https://docs.opensafely.org/data-builder/ehrql/tutorial/ |

We can start with the databuilder (or is it data-builder?) docs since these are unused and we don't have to worry about redirects.

issue.title: Semantic prefixes in PR titles don't trigger a release
issue.body:
By pre-pending "fix:" to [this PR](https://github.com/opensafely/cohort-extractor/pull/240) title, the PR passed the [semantic-pull-requests check](https://github.com/zeke/semantic-pull-requests).

However when merged it didn't then trigger a new release:
```
Analyzing commit: Merge pull request #240 from opensafely/sqlcmd-improvements
fix: Refactor sqlcmd wrapper for better error handling
The commit should not trigger a release
Analyzing commit: Be slightly more defensive against unexpected output
The commit should not trigger a release
Analyzing commit: Refactor sqlcmd wrapper for better error handling
Previously this code used the `-o output_file` option. This caused both
query output and warnings/errors to be mixed together in a single file,
which then required hairy and error prone code to try to separate back
out.

We now just let sqlcmd write to stdout, which we redirect to a file
ourselves, leaving error output written to stderr.

Closes #239
The commit should not trigger a release
Analyzing commit: Test that SQL runtime errors are handled correctly
The commit should not trigger a release
Analyzing commit: Compare contents of files directly in tests
This makes the test failure output more useful as it shows the diff
between the files.
The commit should not trigger a release
Analysis of 5 commits complete: no release
```

I think this is because the merge commit looks like this and doesn't contain "fix:" as its first characters:
```
Merge pull request #240 from opensafely/sqlcmd-improvements
fix: Refactor sqlcmd wrapper for better error handling
```

Ideally the PR check and the action would agree about what constitutes an appropriately annotated PR.

comment.body:
The semantic-pull-requests GitHub app has [long been deprecated](https://github.com/zeke/semantic-pull-requests/commit/b67529a2d661a5c3965cfed2eafe2bd8173fd108), so we're no longer using it here anyway.

But the original issue still stands, so I renamed the issue. The issue is with github-tag-action which still doesn't support PR titles, only the start of commit messages.

issue.title: Enable site preview for Dependabot builds
issue.body:
We're now building the site via GitHub Actions and pushing that to Cloudflare Pages ourselves to deploy the site, following #921.

This requires secrets to deploy. Dependabot does not have access to these secrets (#929). #930 simply skips the publish step for Dependabot PRs, which means you don't get an automatic preview. This isn't too big a problem as most changes are likely fairly innocuous, provided the site builds.

If we want to resolve it, we would either need to: 

* use `pull_request_target` as the workflow trigger (which has [security implications](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-preventing-pwn-requests/) which we would be better avoiding)
* or (probably better) separating build and deploy steps by building the site and uploading artifacts in one workflow, then triggering deployment of those artifacts via `workflow_run`, with secrets access.

Alternatively, if Cloudflare Pages ever improves to allow builds with newer Python, we could consider allowing Cloudflare Pages to do the build and deploy. This removes this problem.

comment.body: Another option is to provide [Dependabot with its own secret](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/dependabot/working-with-dependabot/managing-encrypted-secrets-for-dependabot).

issue.title: Update screenshots regularly

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
# Summary

As mentioned by @ghickman on Slack, we could use something like [shot-scraper](https://github.com/simonw/shot-scraper) to generate screenshots.

This ideally would be automated or, failing that, semi-automated and run by a developer locally.

## Benefits

Inspired by https://twitter.com/aaronbassett/status/1536708194160070658:

* For users, this keeps screenshots up-to-date with the current appearance of web services.
* For developers, these act as simple additional checks, warning us when web services have changed substantially, either when:
  * the layout has changed somewhat, and a new screenshot does not represent what was intended
  * the layout has changed enough that this automation fails

## Questions/ideas

* What's the best way of automating login to external services where necessary?
  * Relevant issue for shot-scraper: https://github.com/simonw/shot-scraper/issues/30
  * Can we configure 2FA for such services to secure test accounts? This seems a little tricky.
* Would some services block GitHub Actions runners? I've seen this when automating link checks.
* For services that we develop, we should probably run them with a GitHub Actions runner to screenshot, instead of trying to login into the production site.
* What about screenshots of, for example, Docker or GitHub Desktop installation processes?
* Do we want to image diff and use that in automation, to determine when to update?

comment.body:
Another problem: annotating screenshots where they have extra labelling. Example: https://github.com/opensafely/documentation/blob/bd84ebf8bc0dd0b9f86fa782bba2fbb94b9b4538/docs/images/adding-codelist-id-tag.png

The current route via shot-scraper is clunky, though there's an [open issue](https://github.com/simonw/shot-scraper/issues/9) to improve it.

pull_request.title: build(deps): bump pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish from 1.6.1 to 1.6.4
pull_request.body:
Bumps [pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish](https://github.com/pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish) from 1.6.1 to 1.6.4.
Release notes

Sourced from pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish's releases.

v1.6.4

oh, boi! again?

This is the last one tonight, promise! It fixes this embarrassing bug that was actually caught by the CI but got overlooked due to the lack of sleep. TL;DR GH passed $HOME from the external env into the container and that tricked the Python's site module to think that the home directory is elsewhere, adding non-existent paths to the env vars. See #115.

Full Diff: https://github.com/pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish/compare/v1.6.3...v1.6.4

v1.6.3

Another Release!? Why?

In pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish#112, it was discovered that passing a $PATH variable even breaks the shebang. So this version adds more safeguards to make sure it keeps working with a fully broken $PATH.

Full Diff: https://github.com/pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish/compare/v1.6.2...v1.6.3

v1.6.2

What's Fixed

  • Made the $PATH and $PYTHONPATH environment variables resilient to broken values passed from the host runner environment, which previously allowed the users to accidentally break the container's internal runtime as reported in pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish#112

Internal Maintenance Improvements

  • Added a devpi-based smoke-test GitHub Actions CI/CD workflow by @​sesdaile-varmour in pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish#111

New Contributors

  • @​sesdaile-varmour made their first contribution in pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish#111

Full Diff: https://github.com/pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish/compare/v1.6.1...v1.6.2

Commits
  • c7f29f7 🐛 Override $HOME in the container with /root
  • 644926c 🧪 Always run smoke testing in debug mode
  • e71a4a4 Add support for verbose bash execusion w/ $DEBUG
  • e56e821 🐛 Make id always available in twine-upload
  • c879b84 🐛 Use full path to bash in shebang
  • 57e7d53 🐛Ensure the default $PATH value is pre-loaded
  • ce291dc 🎨🐛Fix the branch @ pre-commit.ci badge links
  • 102d8ab 🐛 Rehardcode devpi port for GHA srv container
  • 3a9eaef 🐛Use different ports in/out of GHA containers
  • a01fa74 🐛 Use localhost @ GHA outside the containers
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

pull_request.title: build(deps-dev): bump pip-tools from 6.9.0 to 6.11.0
pull_request.body:
Bumps [pip-tools](https://github.com/jazzband/pip-tools) from 6.9.0 to 6.11.0.
Release notes

Sourced from pip-tools's releases.

6.11.0

Features:

  • Add pyproject.toml file (#1643). Thanks @​otherJL0
  • Support build isolation using setuptools/pyproject.toml requirement files (#1727). Thanks @​atugushev

Bug Fixes:

  • Improve punctuation/grammar with pip-compile header (#1547). Thanks @​blueyed
  • Generate hashes for all available candidates (#1723). Thanks @​neykov

Other Changes:

  • Bump click minimum version to >= 8 (#1733). Thanks @​atugushev
  • Bump pip minimum version to >= 22.2 (#1729). Thanks @​atugushev

6.10.0

Features:

  • Deprecate pip-compile --resolver=legacy (#1724). Thanks @​atugushev
  • Prompt user to use the backtracking resolver on errors (#1719). Thanks @​maxfenv
  • Add support for Python 3.11 final (#1708). Thanks @​hugovk
  • Add --newline=[LF|CRLF|native|preserve] option to pip-compile (#1652). Thanks @​AndydeCleyre

Bug Fixes:

  • Fix inconsistent handling of constraints comments with backtracking resolver (#1713). Thanks @​mkniewallner
  • Fix some encoding warnings in Python 3.10 (PEP 597) (#1614). Thanks @​GalaxySnail

Other Changes:

  • Update pip-tools version in the README's pre-commit examples (#1701). Thanks @​Kludex
  • Document use of the backtracking resolver (#1718). Thanks @​maxfenv
  • Use HTTPS in a readme link (#1716). Thanks @​Arhell

pull_request.title: build(deps-dev): bump sqlalchemy from 1.4.43 to 1.4.44
pull_request.body:
Bumps [sqlalchemy](https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy) from 1.4.43 to 1.4.44.
Release notes

Sourced from sqlalchemy's releases.

1.4.44

Released: November 12, 2022

sql

  • [sql] [bug] Fixed critical memory issue identified in cache key generation, where for very large and complex ORM statements that make use of lots of ORM aliases with subqueries, cache key generation could produce excessively large keys that were orders of magnitude bigger than the statement itself. Much thanks to Rollo Konig Brock for their very patient, long term help in finally identifying this issue.

    References: #8790

postgresql

  • [postgresql] [bug] [mssql] For the PostgreSQL and SQL Server dialects only, adjusted the compiler so that when rendering column expressions in the RETURNING clause, the "non anon" label that's used in SELECT statements is suggested for SQL expression elements that generate a label; the primary example is a SQL function that may be emitting as part of the column's type, where the label name should match the column's name by default. This restores a not-well defined behavior that had changed in version 1.4.21 due to #6718, #6710. The Oracle dialect has a different RETURNING implementation and was not affected by this issue. Version 2.0 features an across the board change for its widely expanded support of RETURNING on other backends.

    References: #8770

oracle

  • [oracle] [bug] Fixed issue in the Oracle dialect where an INSERT statement that used insert(some_table).values(...).returning(some_table) against a full Table object at once would fail to execute, raising an exception.

tests

  • [tests] [bug] Fixed issue where the --disable-asyncio parameter to the test suite would fail to not actually run greenlet tests and would also not prevent the suite from using a "wrapping" greenlet for the whole suite. This parameter now ensures that no greenlet or asyncio use will occur within the entire run when set.

    References: #8793

... (truncated)

Commits
  • See full diff in compare view

[![Dependabot compatibility score](https://dependabot-badges.githubapp.com/badges/compatibility_score?dependency-name=sqlalchemy&package-manager=pip&previous-version=1.4.43&new-version=1.4.44)](https://docs.github.com/en/github/managing-security-vulnerabilities/about-dependabot-security-updates#about-compatibility-scores) Dependabot will resolve any conflicts with this PR as long as you don't alter it yourself. issue.title: MSSQL Docker container doesn't run on M1 macs
issue.body:
Just a note for the future that I cannot run tests on databuilder on a M1 mac. Unit tests work fine. The docker container for MSSQL starts and then immediately stops. I have not explored this in great detail as I have the option of switching to an intel. 

Next steps:
- Other mac m1 users try to run tests that require docker to see if problem persist
- If they do, change documentation to indicate this

comment.body:
Upstream issues perhaps worth tracking:

* Microsoft: https://github.com/microsoft/mssql-docker/issues/734
* Docker: https://github.com/docker/roadmap/issues/384

The current workarounds still use colima as mentioned already in this thread.

issue.title: Too many Network errors: Looking for suggestions

labels.name: question
labels.description: Further information is requested

issue.body:
Hey folks, Have been tinkering with Lychee lately to run on static HTML and check about 17k+ links. From those, I am getting about 400+ links resulting in a Network error. I wanted to open an issue here to ask folks if I might be doing something wrong or if something can be improved to mitigate these. 

- Here's my lychee report below: https://github.com/balena-io/docs/issues/2303
- GitHub action: https://github.com/balena-io/docs/blob/master/.github/workflows/link-checker.yml
- `lychee.toml` file: https://github.com/balena-io/docs/blob/master/lychee.toml 

I have set `verbose: true` I wish it could show what the actual HTTP error code is in the report that gets generated.

comment.body:
> information_source **If anyone runs into issues with rate limiting in the future, there is now a troubleshooting guide over at [lychee.cli.rs/#/rate-limits](http://lychee.cli.rs/#/rate-limits).**

The rate limit troubleshooting guide moved to: https://lychee.cli.rs/#/troubleshooting/rate-limits

issue.title: clarify differences in column order WRT dummy data and the backends
issue.body:
The column index of a variable may not be consistent between the dummy data and the backend. Suggest an addition to the [docs](https://docs.opensafely.org/actions-pipelines/) to clarify this. Something along the lines of 

> * The ordering of columns may not be consistent between the dummy data and the TPP/EMIS backend. You should avoid referring to index integer positions and instead use the index names.

issue.title: Improve documentation for installing docker on Windows Home

labels.name: improve content
labels.description: Improve existing documentation content

issue.body:
This is what the [official docs](https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-windows/install-windows-home/) have to say:


* Hyper-V and Containers Windows features must be enabled.
* The following hardware prerequisites are required to successfully run Client Hyper-V on Windows 10:
  * 64 bit processor with Second Level Address Translation (SLAT)
  * 4GB system RAM
  * BIOS-level hardware virtualization support must be enabled in the BIOS settings. For more information, see Virtualization.


Our test user has a "very late" build of Windows 10 Home: they went through the requirements trying to find out if they had SLAT.  They added:

> I  couldn’t get the virtualization stuff to work either.
>
> There were a series of more & more complex things for a simpleton like me to do with Hyper-V and Containers Windows. I also enabled WSL1 but didn’t get WSL2 to go.
>
> I don’t know if I was close to getting it going, but each time I got something, I found there was another 2 levels to negotiate.

comment.body:
Windows Home doesn't have Hyper-V support.

But installation on Windows Home should be simpler now: Windows Home does support WSL2 and WSL2 is now the default recommendation from Docker for Docker Desktop. You do still require hardware that supports virtualisation (in other words, Intel VT-x or AMD-V), and that feature to be enabled in the BIOS, if it isn't by default.

issue.title: Integrate data ingestion dates

labels.name: new content
labels.description: New documentation content

issue.body:
Somehow, we want to get the information from [this notebook](https://github.com/opensafely/rapid-reports/blob/master/notebooks/latest-dates.ipynb) into the documentation.

The simplest iteration is to confirm we are allow to publish it without NHSE approval; then link to it from the docs.

The better iteration is to convert the notebook into a project pipeline (this will also require study definition support for querying build time metadata from the backend); get it to output the result as markdown, and write that directly to this repo (via a PR).

comment.body:
@sebbacon: Reviewing this old issue, the current state is:

* the new-since-this-issue-was-originally-opened reports site contains the [database report](https://reports.opensafely.org/reports/opensafely-tpp-database-builds/)
* the [documentation site](https://docs.opensafely.org/data-sources/systmone/#opensafely-tpp-database-coverage-and-metadata) links to the database report

Is there anything else needed here? Would we still want to integrate this data more tightly into the docs site?
